challengeDetails.title: From EarthData to Action: Cloud Computing with Earth Observation Data for Predicting Cleaner, Safer Skies
challengeDetails.excerpt: NASA‚Äôs Tropospheric Emissions: Monitoring of Pollution (TEMPO) mission is revolutionizing air quality monitoring across North America by enabling better forecasts and reducing pollutant exposure. Your challenge is to develop a web-based app that forecasts air quality by integrating real-time TEMPO data with ground-based air quality measurements and weather data, notifying users of poor air quality, and helping to improve public health decisions. Teams are encouraged to utilize new technologies that allow seamless scaling of computing from local devices to cloud systems, enhancing collaboration and streamlining work efficiency. (Earth Science Division)

challengeDetails.title: Sharks from Space
challengeDetails.excerpt: Earth‚Äôs ocean is one of the most powerful habitats in our universe, supporting a range of life that sustains ecosystems and habitability across the globe. It is common to measure photosynthetic activity in the ocean from space, but far more challenging to track top predators. Your challenge is to create a mathematical framework for identifying sharks and predicting their foraging habitats using NASA satellite data, and also to suggest a new conceptual model of a tag (a small electronic device that can be attached to an animal to track and study its movement) that could measure not only where sharks are, but also what they are eating, and in real time transmit that data back to users to enable development of predictive models. (Earth Science Division)

challengeDetails.title: BloomWatch: An Earth Observation Application for Global Flowering Phenology
challengeDetails.excerpt: Witness the pulse of life across our planet! From season to season and year to year, Earth‚Äôs vegetation is constantly changing, providing critical information on plant species, crops, seasonal effects, pollen sources, and changes in plant phenology (the relationship between seasonal changes and climate and biological phenomena in plants). Your challenge is to harness the power of NASA Earth observations to create a dynamic visual tool that displays and/or detects plant blooming events around the globe‚Äîjust like pollinators do‚Äìand that advances solutions for monitoring, predicting, or managing vegetation. (Earth Science Division)

challengeDetails.title: Embiggen Your Eyes!

NASA‚Äôs space missions continue to push the boundaries of what is technologically possible, providing high-resolution images and videos of Earth, other planets, and space with billions or even trillions of pixels. Your challenge is to create a platform that allows users to zoom in and out on these massive image datasets, label known features, and discover new patterns. (Astrophysics Division)

projectDetails.name: Guardions Of Jalap√£o
projectDetails.summary:
We are the Alpha Mackenzie team, Brazilian middle school students, and we developed the project "Guardians of Jalap√£o," which addresses the favorable Brazilian climate conditions for harvesting Golden Grass. Inspired by the proposed challenge and the Golden Grass Women's Project, which uses sustainable agricultural practices for the production and harvesting of golden grass, our goal was to develop an educational game to raise awareness about the importance of such initiatives that use natural resources through sustainable management based on ideal climate conditions.

Therefore, the relevance of this project lies in simulating a resource collection scenario (temperature, precipitation, and soil moisture) and providing players with information about the correct and ideal management of golden grass harvesting. This game is intended to be made available to students as a way to raise awareness about sustainability and proper golden grass management. Additionally, it could be displayed in museums and at the headquarters of the Golden Grass Women's Project to highlight the ideal conditions and the consequences of resource collection according to the seasons.
projectDetails.details:
We are the Alpha Mackenzie team, and our project, "Guardians of Jalap√£o," is aligned with Sustainable Development Goal (SDG) 15, which focuses on life on land. That‚Äôs why we chose to work with Golden Grass ‚Äî a resource widely used in the Jalap√£o region for the production of handicrafts that generate income for local communities ‚Äî by understanding the most favorable climate conditions for its growth and harvest.

We developed a game using the tools available on Scratch, with the main purpose of raising awareness about the harvesting of Golden Grass in the Jalap√£o region, based on the climate characteristics we researched and how they affect the collection of this resource. The game‚Äôs primary goal is to promote awareness about the extraction of Golden Grass and how it grows throughout the seasons of the year. It serves as a tool to present the data and information collected, helping the public understand and become more conscious of this issue.

Golden Grass (Syngonanthus nitens) is a plant native to the Brazilian Cerrado, especially found in Jalap√£o (Tocantins state). It is used to make handicrafts that symbolize the local culture, such as bags and jewelry. Its sustainable harvesting is regulated by the Tocantins Nature Institute (Naturatins) to ensure the conservation of the species. The grass is harvested annually after the seeds mature.

We collected data using Google Earth Engine and selected the Jalap√£o region, where Golden Grass is most abundantly produced. Additionally, we uploaded a script with commands to retrieve climate characteristics such as temperature, precipitation, and soil moisture from last year (2024). Our main focus was on precipitation and temperature.

Based on this information, we identified the climate characteristics and associated them with their impact on the production and harvesting of Golden Grass, allowing us to understand the reactions caused by these factors. The game uses this data to show the player what happens depending on the amount of resources collected during gameplay.

"Guardians of Jalap√£o" runs, as mentioned earlier, on Scratch ‚Äî a free, open-source visual programming language developed at MIT to teach coding in a fun and accessible way. The user will access a link that redirects them to the game on Scratch. In the game, the player controls a character and collects clouds (precipitation), a thermometer (temperature), and a soil bar (soil moisture). Depending on the number of items the user collects, the outcome will change according to the climate conditions of Jalap√£o for each season.

The ideal time for the player to achieve the best result is during spring, as it is the favorable season for harvesting Golden Grass in the region ‚Äî a dry and arid period. If the user collects values that differ from the ideal, the game will inform them of the current season and its impact on the Golden Grass.

With this project, we aim to show how closely climate characteristics are linked to the development and harvesting of Golden Grass ‚Äî a vital resource for income generation in the Jalap√£o region. Furthermore, one of our goals is to bring the game to museums in the Cerrado region, especially those that focus on this biome, or to communities that work with this resource, particularly the "Golden Grass Women's Project." There, tourists could learn about the differences in Brazil‚Äôs seasons and how they affect the harvesting of this plant. In this way, the game could be commercialized and made available for use in these locations (museums and community centers).

Therefore, the target audience for the game includes the communities that work with Golden Grass, organizations or institutions that deal with this resource or the Cerrado biome, and tourists visiting the aforementioned locations.

For the development of our project, we used the following technologies:

Scratch: A visual programming platform and block-based coding language that allows users to create games, animations, and interactive stories by dragging and dropping visual commands instead of writing complex code ‚Äî used for creating the game developed by the team.

Google Earth Engine (a tool recommended by NASA): A geospatial data science platform that provides a massive catalog of satellite imagery and geographic data, along with cloud computing infrastructure for planetary-scale analysis ‚Äî used for collecting, comparing, and analyzing climate data.

projectDetails.name: Project Angelus Novus
projectDetails.summary:
For the challenge NASA Farm Navigators: Using NASA Data Exploration in Agriculture, we developed Farm Navigators, an educational strategy card game designed to make complex Earth science data accessible and engaging. Players take the role of agricultural decision-makers, balancing four pillars ‚Äî Economy, Sustainability, Technology, and People ‚Äî while making choices about irrigation, fertilization, and livestock management. Each decision carries trade-offs, teaching that agriculture involves dilemmas rather than perfect solutions.

Our game integrates real NASA datasets: NDVI/EVI (MODIS & Landsat) to monitor vegetation health, SMAP for soil moisture, GPM for precipitation, and MODIS LST for land surface temperature. These datasets inform the scenarios presented in the cards, grounding decisions in real-world science.

To enrich the narrative, we created Little Eliot, an AI Agent acting as a Narrative Consequence Analyst. Eliot provides short, subtly ironic reflections on each decision and, at the end of the game, the player‚Äôs results are added to a shared database. This allows participants to compare outcomes, fostering collective learning and a sense of responsibility for the world.
projectDetails.details:
Project Details ‚Äì Farm Navigators

What it does / how it works
Farm Navigators is an educational strategy card game that simulates real farming decisions using NASA‚Äôs open datasets. Players must balance four pillars ‚Äî Economy, Sustainability, Technology, and People ‚Äî while managing irrigation, fertilization, and livestock. Each choice triggers trade-offs, showing that agriculture is a world of dilemmas rather than perfect solutions.

Benefits & Intended Impact
The game makes complex NASA Earth data accessible and engaging, helping players of all ages understand how environmental variables affect food production, sustainability, and social well-being. By linking real satellite data to everyday farming scenarios, it promotes climate awareness, sustainable practices, and data-driven thinking. The collective database of player results encourages reflection on global responsibility, as participants can compare whether their choices ‚Äúhelped or harmed the world.‚Äù

AI Integration ‚Äì Little Eliot
We created Little Eliot, an AI Agent acting as a Narrative Consequence Analyst. After each decision, Eliot generates short, subtly ironic commentaries suggesting possible futures. At the end, progress is recorded in a shared database, fostering a sense of community and collective learning.

Tools, Languages, and Frameworks
We combined modern tools to develop the project:

  • Lovable, Langflow, Cursor ‚Äì for AI workflows and prototyping.
  • React & TypeScript ‚Äì for the front-end interface.
  • FastAPI & MongoDB ‚Äì for backend logic and database storage.
  • ChatGPT-5 nano ‚Äì powering Eliot‚Äôs generative AI responses.

Creativity & Design Considerations
We designed Farm Navigators to merge serious data with playful storytelling, blending strategy, education, and irony. Our key considerations were scientific accuracy, player engagement, and scalability, ensuring the game can grow into classrooms, communities, and global platforms.
projectDetails.aiReferences:
Use of Artificial Intelligence (AI)

Our project makes purposeful use of AI in both its game design and technical development:

  1. Narrative Gameplay ‚Äì Little Eliot
    • We created Little Eliot, an AI Agent acting as a Narrative Consequence Analyst.
    • Eliot uses a fine-tuned prompt with ChatGPT-5 nano to generate short, subtly ironic narrative commentaries after each player decision.
    • These outputs enrich the storytelling by suggesting possible consequences without referencing scores or game mechanics.
  2. Backend Development Support
    • We used AI-assisted tools (such as Langflow, Cursor, and Lovable) to accelerate prototyping, workflow orchestration, and prompt optimization.
  3. Content Creation
    • Draft texts, gameplay scenarios, and narrative examples were initially generated with AI, then refined by our team.
    • All AI-generated texts were reviewed and edited to align with the project‚Äôs educational goals.
  4. Code and Data
    • Portions of boilerplate code and database handling were generated using AI tools to speed up development.
    • Metadata and documentation acknowledge AI contributions.

Compliance Measures

  • No NASA logos, mission identifiers, or official branding were generated or modified by AI.
  • Any AI-generated visuals or audio (if used in later stages) will carry visible AI-generated watermarks and proper metadata acknowledgments.

Through this integration, AI was not used to replace originality but to accelerate creativity, enhance gameplay, and prototype faster while keeping the final vision and design firmly in the hands of our team.

challengeDetails.title: Meteor Madness
challengeDetails.excerpt: A newly identified near-Earth asteroid, "Impactor-2025," poses a potential threat to Earth, but do we have the tools to enable the public and decision makers to understand and mitigate its risks? NASA datasets include information about known asteroids and the United States Geological Survey provides critical information that could enable modeling the effects of asteroid impacts, but this data needs to be integrated to enable effective visualization and decision making. Your challenge is to develop an interactive visualization and simulation tool that uses real data to help users model asteroid impact scenarios, predict consequences, and evaluate potential mitigation strategies. (Planetary Science Division)

challengeDetails.title: A World Away: Hunting for Exoplanets with AI
challengeDetails.excerpt: Data from several different space-based exoplanet surveying missions have enabled discovery of thousands of new planets outside our solar system, but most of these exoplanets were identified manually. With advances in artificial intelligence and machine learning (AI/ML), it is possible to automatically analyze large sets of data collected by these missions to identify exoplanets. Your challenge is to create an AI/ML model that is trained on one or more of the open-source exoplanet datasets offered by NASA and that can analyze new data to accurately identify exoplanets. (Astrophysics Division)

challengeDetails.title: Stellar Stories: Space Weather Through the Eyes of Earthlings

Your challenge is to write and illustrate a digital children‚Äôs story that explains what space weather is and the varying impacts it has on different people such as farmers, pilots, astronauts, power grid operators, and the general public. You can tell the story from the perspective of a person impacted by space weather or from the point of view of a solar flare or coronal mass ejection (CME) as it approaches Earth. (Heliophysics Division)

(Earth Science Division)

projectDetails.name: Project Brazuca - Plantando o Futuro
projectDetails.summary:
Education faces a major challenge: effectively integrating technology to engage students and develop citizens who are aware of the environmental and social impacts of human activities. While public policies and traditional methods are progressing slowly, new generations demand practical, up-to-date experiences connected to the real world.

Our solution addresses this challenge with an educational game that uses real-time NASA data to simulate agricultural scenarios in different regions of Brazil. The player chooses a crop and a state (for example, planting coffee in Rio Grande do Sul) and the system analyzes climate, terrain, and environmental events to demonstrate the viability and impacts of this choice. Wildfires, climate variations, and other real-world phenomena are automatically captured and directly affect crops in the game, connecting students to the living dynamics of the environment.

The result is an innovative tool that combines hands-on learning, gamification, and reliable scientific data to transform environmental education. In this initial phase, we're starting in Brazil, but our vision is global: to bring this interactive experience to schools and players worldwide, fostering collaboration, knowledge exchange, and planetary awareness.
projectDetails.details:
1. WHAT DOES IT DO OR HOW DOES IT WORK

Plantando Futuro (‚ÄúPlanting the Future‚Äù) is an educational simulation game that teaches sustainable agriculture and climate awareness through interactive gameplay.
The application allows users to simulate the entire agricultural production cycle across Brazil‚Äôs 27 states using real NASA and INMET climate data.
Players select from 13 crops across 5 agricultural sectors (Agriculture, Livestock, Aquaculture, Forestry, and Horticulture), manage resources, respond to real-time environmental alerts, and earn sustainability-based rewards.

1.1 Core Functionality

  1. User Authentication and Profile Management:
    Secure login via Supabase Auth with persistent user profiles and multiple game slots per account.
  2. Crop and Location Selection:
    Interactive map of Brazil where players choose crops and states.
    Each state uses real geographic coordinates to fetch climate data.
  3. Pre-Planting Viability Analysis:
    The system calculates the compatibility between selected crop and regional conditions using NASA POWER data (temperature, rainfall, humidity, evapotranspiration).
  4. Production Cycle Simulation:
    Players advance through a 120-day virtual growing season, completing management tasks such as irrigation, pest control, and fertilization.
    The system dynamically generates events like droughts, floods, or fires using NASA and INMET data.
  5. Real-Time Climate Alerts:
    Integrations with NASA FIRMS and INMET APIs provide real-time wildfire and meteorological alerts that directly affect gameplay variables such as crop health and sustainability score.
  6. Scoring and Feedback:
    Final performance is based on a weighted formula:
    • Health (40%)
    • Sustainability (30%)
    • Water Efficiency (30%)
      Players earn medals (Gold, Silver, Bronze) and can compare results in a dashboard.
  7. Progressive Web App (PWA):
    Fully installable on mobile and desktop, with offline functionality and caching for low-connectivity environments.

2. WHAT BENEFITS DOES IT HAVE

  1. Educational Value:
    Simplifies complex climate and agricultural concepts through interactive simulation.
    Players learn how environmental decisions influence sustainability and productivity.
  2. Real Data Integration:
    Uses verified NASA and INMET data, ensuring scientific accuracy and trustworthiness.
  3. Engagement through Gamification:
    Combines education with entertainment, enhancing user retention and motivation.
  4. Accessibility and Inclusion:
    PWA support enables access on any device, even in low-bandwidth areas.
    Interface available in Portuguese and English for broader reach.
  5. Environmental Awareness:
    Encourages critical thinking about sustainability and responsible resource management.

3. WHAT IS THE INTENDED IMPACT OF THE PROJECT

  1. Educational Transformation:
    Converts environmental science into an engaging, visual, and practical learning experience.
    Players can understand the link between climate data and agricultural outcomes in real time.
  2. Critical Thinking and Responsibility:
    Demonstrates how local decisions affect global sustainability.
    Encourages reflection on water usage, emissions, and biodiversity.
  3. Regional and Social Inclusion:
    Promotes awareness of Brazil‚Äôs diverse climates and ecosystems.
    Provides accessible educational material for schools, NGOs, and rural communities.
  4. Institutional Adoption:
    Designed to serve as an educational resource for schools and environmental programs.
    Can be used in classrooms or workshops to complement sustainability education.
  5. Long-Term Awareness:
    Aims to build lasting environmental responsibility and inspire young generations to consider sustainability in real-world decision-making.

4. WHAT TOOLS, CODING LANGUAGES, HARDWARE, OR SOFTWARE WERE USED

4.1 Frontend Stack

  • React 18.3.1: Component-based UI framework.
  • TypeScript: Static typing and compile-time validation.
  • Vite: High-speed development build tool.
  • Tailwind CSS: Responsive utility-first styling.
  • shadcn/ui: Accessible UI components (based on Radix UI).
  • Zustand 5.0.8: Lightweight global state management.
  • React Router DOM 6.30.1: Protected route management.
  • React Hook Form + Zod: Validation and schema enforcement.
  • Recharts 2.15.4: Data visualization.
  • date-fns 3.6.0: Date and time handling.

4.2 Backend Infrastructure

  • Supabase: Backend-as-a-Service (PostgreSQL, Auth, and Edge Functions).
  • Supabase Auth: Secure authentication with JWT.
  • Row-Level Security: User-level data isolation.
  • Deno Edge Functions: Serverless integrations for NASA and INMET APIs.

4.3 External APIs

  • NASA POWER API: Climate variables (temperature, humidity, precipitation, evapotranspiration).
  • NASA FIRMS API: Real-time wildfire alerts (VIIRS satellite).
  • INMET API: Brazilian meteorological warnings.

4.4 Deployment and Hardware

  • Hosting: Lovable Cloud (auto-deploy via Git push).
  • Database: Supabase PostgreSQL.
  • Devices: Any modern web browser (desktop or mobile).
  • Connectivity: Internet for real-time data; offline support via PWA caching.

5. HOW IS THE PROJECT CREATIVE

  1. Real Satellite Data Integration:
    First educational game to combine NASA POWER (climate) and FIRMS (fire) data for interactive sustainability simulation.
  2. Dynamic Environmental Gameplay:
    Real-time data directly influences the player‚Äôs outcomes ‚Äî fires, droughts, and rainfall events generate immediate feedback and learning moments.
  3. Gamified Learning Framework:
    Transforms scientific knowledge into an engaging experience through challenges, scoring systems, and medal rewards.
  4. Cross-Disciplinary Approach:
    Combines data science, game design, and environmental education into a unified, accessible tool.
  5. Visual and UX Creativity:
    Uses pixel-art style and simple interactive dashboards to make complex climate data intuitive for all audiences.

6. WHAT FACTORS DID THE TEAM CONSIDER

  1. Pedagogical Design:
    Educational balance between scientific accuracy and accessible learning for ages 10 and up.
    Concepts simplified without losing data integrity.
  2. Accessibility and Inclusivity:
    Compliance with WCAG accessibility standards and full keyboard navigation.
    Color contrast verified for color blindness.
  3. Localization:
    Native Portuguese interface with English translation.
    Temperature and precipitation units adapted per locale.
  4. Scalability:
    Modular architecture allows adding new crops or data sources easily.
    APIs abstracted via edge functions for rapid expansion.
  5. Resilience and Offline Access:
    Built as a Progressive Web App to support unstable internet connections common in rural areas.
  6. Cultural Context:
    All examples, crops, and terminology based on Brazilian agriculture, ensuring local relevance while maintaining global applicability.

Conclusion

Plantando Futuro is an innovative educational platform that merges space technology, climate data, and game design to raise awareness about sustainable agriculture.
By transforming real NASA and INMET data into interactive learning, it enables players to understand ‚Äî in an intuitive, hands-on way ‚Äî how environmental conditions shape the world we live in.

projectDetails.name: Exoplanet Classification Tool
projectDetails.summary:
We developed the Exoplanet Classification Tool, an interactive web application that leverages a machine learning model to classify exoplanet candidates from NASA's Kepler mission data. The primary challenge in the field is efficiently vetting the vast number of potential signals (KOIs) to identify the most promising candidates.

Our tool addresses this by allowing researchers to upload their data and receive an instant classification of each object as 'CONFIRMED' or 'FALSE POSITIVE', based on a high-accuracy (99%) Random Forest model. Crucially, the tool goes beyond simple prediction. For each classification, it provides a detailed technical justification using SHAP (SHapley Additive exPlanations), showing exactly which astronomical parameters most influenced the decision.

This is important because by providing fast, accurate, and interpretable classifications, the tool serves as a powerful decision-support resource, helping astronomers prioritize candidates, building trust in the AI's results, and accelerating the pace of exoplanet discovery.
projectDetails.details:
The Exoplanet Classification Tool is a web application designed to automate and accelerate the vetting of potential exoplanets. The workflow is simple and direct:

  1. Data Upload: An astronomer or researcher submits a CSV file containing data for exoplanet candidates (Kepler Objects of Interest - KOIs).
    • Feature Selection: From the raw data, the system selects only the 52 features that proved most predictive in the original data analysis. Columns with a high percentage of missing values, identifiers (kepid), redundant data, and parameters not directly related to the transit's physical properties were systematically removed.
    • Missing Data Handling: If any of the 52 essential features are missing from the user's file (or contain empty cells), the system automatically fills them with pre-calculated average values from the original training dataset, ensuring consistency.
  2. AI Classification: The clean data is then fed into a high-accuracy (99%) Random Forest machine learning model, which classifies each candidate as either "CONFIRMED" or "FALSE POSITIVE".
  3. Visualization and Analysis: The results are presented in an interactive interface featuring a dashboard, tables, and most importantly, an Individual Analysis section. Here, a researcher can select any candidate and view a graph (SHAP Force Plot) and a detailed technical justification that explains exactly which factors led to that specific classification.

The primary benefit of the tool is efficiency and trust. The process of vetting exoplanet candidates is time-consuming and complex. Our tool drastically reduces the time required for an initial screening, allowing researchers to focus on the most promising candidates.

The intended impact is to accelerate the pace of exoplanet discovery. By providing not only a fast and accurate classification but also a transparent explanation of the "why" behind each AI decision, the tool serves as a powerful decision-support resource. It enables astronomers to prioritize targets for follow-up observations with more powerful telescopes, optimizing resources and speeding up the confirmation of new worlds.

The project was developed entirely with open-source software, requiring no specific hardware.

  • Programming Language: Python
  • Backend (Artificial Intelligence): Scikit-learn (for the Random Forest model), Pandas (for data manipulation), and Joblib (for model serialization).
  • Frontend (Web Interface): Streamlit.
  • Data Visualization: Plotly and Matplotlib.
  • AI Explainability: SHAP (SHapley Additive exPlanations), a state-of-the-art library for interpreting machine learning model predictions.

The project's creativity lies in the integration of three complex components into a single, simple, and accessible tool. We combined:

  1. A high-performance machine learning model.
  2. An AI explainability framework (SHAP) that "translates" the model's decisions.
  3. An interactive and intuitive user interface.

Instead of being a "black box," the tool makes the AI's decision-making transparent and understandable to domain experts (astrophysicists), who can validate whether the model's reasoning is scientifically sound. This bridge between advanced data science and practical application in astronomical research is the project's main creative distinction.

The key factors considered were:

  • Scientific Rigor: Ensuring the AI model was trained and validated with a robust methodology (cross-validation) to achieve high accuracy and reliability.
  • User Experience (UX): Designing a clean, minimalist, and intuitive interface that would allow a researcher to use the tool without needing expertise in programming or machine learning.
  • Interpretability: The most important factor. From the outset, the project was designed with the idea that the explanation behind a classification was as crucial as the classification itself. We wanted the tool to build trust, not just provide answers.
projectDetails.aiReferences: Audio Generation: The audio narration for the project's presentation video was created with the assistance of the AI voice synthesis tool, Luvvoice.

projectDetails.name: Project Cosbit
projectDetails.summary: What I developed was software that uses a Space Biological Agent and a Data Analyst Agent to analyze and understand documents from space biology experiments and provide practical and objective insights and valuable information from the documents, thus transforming raw data into intelligent data ready for human decision-making and interpretation.This way, the productivity and gains in the work of researchers, scientists, enthusiasts, etc., increase by trying to assimilate and understand what the data is saying.
projectDetails.details:
What benefits does BioExpace offer?

It can extract any data structure you want from the document and provide you with intelligent information based on the context given to it.

This summarizes a lot of manual work and saves human time and energy from reading and understanding numerous documents.

This way, you can get straight to the point. The data is about Space Biology,

which is essential for understanding how life transforms and adapts in space.

BioExpace offers a bridge between knowledge and data generated by NASA professionals

and modern intelligence capable of transforming how you perceive data.

What is the intended impact of the project?

To gather raw data and be able to display valuable information to the end human user, it takes

all the sections (for example, Introduction, Results, Conclusion) of all documents,

analyzes everything, and generates in a practical and useful way information that may be valuable to you,

information that you might spend hours analyzing to find what you're looking for.

Which tools, programming languages, hardware, or software did you use to develop your project?

  • Languages: Python, HTML, CSS, and JavaScript
  • Frameworks:
  • Flask (good for microservices),
  • Ollama (for integrating LLMs on my local machine),
  • TikToken (for token control by chunk)
  • Database: PostgreSQL (used to store data collection, agent pipelines, and the structure of the final result)
  • Final Data Format: JSON (JSONB in PostgreSQL)
  • Hardware: Local server with only CPU, 16GB of RAM, Ubuntu operating system, no cloud dependency.

How is your project creative?

It uses text comprehension models (NLP) to analyze thousands of tokens in documents, assimilate everything, organize everything

and generate valuable information. It allows quick access to information and the possible generation

of new biological hypotheses thanks to what the Agents provide to us humans.

Furthermore, the idea of collaborative cognitive agents (one reads, another interprets) and the fusion of spatial

biology and intelligent data (thanks to AI), the notion of augmented science, and the way

data is transformed into intelligent information for this branch of science.

There are two agents working on multiple scientific documents, reviewing and generating information

What factors did your team consider?

The fact is that today, we humans are always needing more convenience, more objectivity, more speed.

Tools like this, which save 85% of your work time, make you more productive, not to mention that, of course,

the better the LLM model used, the smarter and better your final result will be. We solved that problem of scattered and possibly meaningless data,

bringing relevance in a simple and objective way, whatever your purpose may be. We solve and facilitate your exploration of the data
projectDetails.aiReferences:
In addition to using Qween and LLama for data analysis, I used ChatGPT during development for the frontend; it helped me with corrections in JavaScript, some HTML definitions, and quick styling.

I defined how I wanted the design to look, and he styled it in CSS. I started developing some frontend-backend integrations and requested corrections in the JavaScript in cases of errors.

challengeDetails.title: Build a Space Biology Knowledge Engine
challengeDetails.excerpt: Enable a new era of human space exploration! Your challenge is to build a dynamic dashboard that leverages artificial intelligence (AI), knowledge graphs, and/or other tools to summarize a set of NASA bioscience publications and enables users to explore the impacts and results of the experiments these publications describe. (Earth Science Division)

(Planetary Science Division)

projectDetails.details:

challengeDetails.title: Sharks from Space

Your challenge is to create a mathematical framework for identifying sharks and predicting their foraging habitats using NASA satellite data, and also to suggest a new conceptual model of a tag (a small electronic device that can be attached to an animal to track and study its movement) that could measure not only where sharks are, but also what they are eating, and in real time transmit that data back to users to enable development of predictive models. (Earth Science Division)

You can tell the story from the perspective of a person impacted by space weather or from the point of view of a solar flare or coronal mass ejection (CME) as it approaches Earth. (Heliophysics Division)

projectDetails.name: OrC (Orbital Clean)
projectDetails.summary: We developed OrC (Orbital Clean), a substation focused on transforming space debris in metallic wires which will be sold down on Earth for multiple purposes. This project contemplates the challenge of commercializing the Low Earth Orbit (LEO), presenting a viable destination for the metals filling the space in the first few thousand meters outside of the Earth. With OrC, we will guarantee the possibility of space navigation and exploration in the future, given the increasing number of space debris should prevent missions from being launched in the next few decades. Ultimately, OrC aims to reuse and commercialize what used to be considered space trash.
projectDetails.details:
What does it do or how does it work?¬†

OrC is responsible for capturing debris collected through a hatch in one of the bases of the cylindric structure, performing a wire drawing process on the inside in order to transform these metals into wires and storing them in boxes that will eventually be ejected back to Earth with the help of an attached parachute.

What benefits does it have?¬†

  • First, we aim to reduce the number of space debris around the Low Earth Orbit in order to avoid future trouble in regards to humanities‚Äô space development.¬†
  • Second, our focus is on giving purpose and market value to the debris through their refinement and transformation into wires.

What is the intended impact of the project?¬†

Transform space debris into a commercialized product by turning them into raw material to be sold on Earth, benefiting both the space market as well as ensuring safety to the future missions.¬†

What tools, coding languages, hardware, or software did you use to develop your project?¬†

N/A

How is your project creative?¬†

The search for innovation and the need of a solution to the space debris overflow are combined though an effective solution in the execution of this project in reason of both the approach to the recycling matter but also addressing the lack of specific raw materials.

What factors did your team consider?

The need for solution to this reoccurring problem in LEO, redirecting what would potentially become an obstacle for space navigation and exploration into a product to be commercialized on Earth.

projectDetails.name: Project FarmFlux
projectDetails.summary:
Farm Flux is an interactive educational game that simulates sustainable agriculture using real NASA satellite data from the POWER API. Players manage virtual farms by making data-driven decisions about crop planting, irrigation, fertilization, and livestock management based on actual climate conditions.

The game addresses the NASA Farm Navigators challenge by integrating real-time temperature, precipitation, humidity, and wind data to demonstrate how satellite information can inform modern agricultural practices. Players learn the environmental and economic impacts of their decisions through a sustainability scoring system (Grade A-F) and educational feedback.

This matters because it bridges the gap between space technology and practical farming education. By visualizing 30-day climate trends and showing how weather directly affects crop growth, Farm Flux teaches farmers, students, and agricultural professionals how NASA's open data can optimize resource efficiency and promote sustainable farming methods‚Äîcrucial for food security in a changing climate.
projectDetails.details:
Farm Flux¬†is an interactive web-based agricultural simulation game that integrates real-time NASA satellite data to teach sustainable farming practices. Players create virtual farms at real GPS coordinates and make data-driven decisions about crop management, irrigation, fertilization, and livestock handling.

Core Mechanics:

  • Players input farm coordinates (e.g., S√£o Paulo: -23.5505, -46.6333)
  • NASA POWER API fetches real climate data (temperature, precipitation, humidity, wind) using MERRA-2 satellite measurements
  • Players plant crops (corn, wheat, soybean, rice, cotton) that grow automatically based on actual weather conditions
  • Every agricultural activity (9 types: organic/chemical fertilization, drip/sprinkler/flood irrigation, rotational/free-range/intensive grazing) generates educational feedback and impacts sustainability scores
  • 30-day climate trend charts visualize temperature and rainfall patterns
  • Sustainability scoring system (Grade A-F) evaluates environmental impact

üåü Benefits & Impact

Educational Benefits:

  1. Data Literacy: Students learn to interpret NASA satellite data for practical applications
  2. Sustainability Awareness: Visual feedback shows environmental consequences of farming choices
  3. Climate Understanding: 30-day trend charts demonstrate weather patterns' impact on agriculture
  4. Decision Making: Players balance economic costs vs. environmental sustainability

Real-World Impact:

  • For Farmers: Demonstrates how free NASA data can optimize resource efficiency (water, fertilizer)
  • For Students: Gamified learning about precision agriculture and climate science
  • For Educators: Ready-to-use tool for teaching sustainable agriculture concepts
  • For Communities: Promotes food security awareness in changing climate conditions

üõ†Ô∏è Technology Stack

Backend:

  • Laravel 12.0¬†(PHP 8.4) - Game logic, NASA API integration
  • SQLite/MySQL¬†- Storing farms, crops, weather data, activities
  • Composer¬†- Dependency management

Frontend:

  • Vue 3.5¬†(TypeScript) - Reactive UI components
  • Inertia.js 2.0¬†- SPA framework bridging Laravel & Vue
  • Vite 7.0¬†- Fast HMR (Hot Module Replacement)
  • Tailwind CSS 4.1¬†- Responsive styling
  • Chart.js¬†- Data visualization (30-day climate trends)
  • Reka UI¬†- Accessible component library
  • Lucide Icons¬†- Modern icon system

External APIs:

  • NASA POWER API¬†- Real satellite data from MERRA-2 (Modern-Era Retrospective Analysis)
  • Parameters fetched: T2M (temperature), PRECTOTCORR (precipitation), RH2M (humidity), WS2M (wind speed)

DevOps:

  • Git¬†- Version control
  • NPM¬†- Frontend package management
  • Artisan¬†- Laravel CLI for migrations, seeding, commands

üé® Creative Elements

1. Gamification Design:

  • Emoji-based feedback system¬†(‚úÖüåçüíß‚ö†Ô∏èüí°) makes learning engaging
  • Grade system¬†(A-F) inspired by academic scoring for familiarity
  • Toast notifications¬†provide instant gratification/warning
  • Progress bars¬†visualize abstract concepts (soil quality, water level)

2. Data Visualization Innovation:

  • Dual-axis chart: Temperature line + precipitation bars in one view
  • Trend badges¬†(üî• Warming / üßä Cooling / ‚öñÔ∏è Stable) simplify complex climate data
  • Color coding: Red (hot/critical), blue (water), green (healthy), orange (warning)

3. Educational Approach:

  • Contextual tips: "Drip irrigation saves up to 50% more water than traditional methods"
  • Predictive feedback: "Optimal weather for fertilization! Plants can best absorb nutrients now"
  • Comparative costs: Shows economic vs. environmental trade-offs ($50-$200/hectare)

4. Realistic Simulation:

  • Automatic crop growth¬†based on real weather (runs hourly via Laravel scheduler)
  • Growth stages: seedling ‚Üí vegetative ‚Üí flowering ‚Üí ripening ‚Üí mature
  • Harvest readiness: Crops mature only after sufficient days + favorable conditions

üß† Design Considerations

1. Accessibility:

  • Keyboard navigation: Full ARIA support via Reka UI components
  • Screen reader friendly: Semantic HTML, proper labels
  • Tooltips: Hover and focus states for information
  • Color contrast: WCAG AA compliant

2. Performance:

  • API caching: Weather data cached to minimize NASA API calls
  • Lazy loading: Components load on-demand
  • Optimistic UI updates: Instant feedback while API processes
  • Debounced inputs: Form validation doesn't trigger on every keystroke

3. Scalability:

  • Modular architecture: Services pattern (NasaWeatherService, FarmSimulationService)
  • Database migrations: Version-controlled schema changes
  • Factory & Seeders: Easy demo data generation
  • Policy-based authorization: Secure multi-user support ready

4. User Experience:

  • Empty states: Motivational messages when no crops planted
  • Loading states: Skeleton loaders prevent jarring content shifts
  • Error handling: Friendly messages instead of technical errors
  • Progressive disclosure: Advanced features revealed gradually

5. Educational Integrity:

  • Real data only: No fake/simulated climate data
  • Scientific accuracy: Fertilizer/irrigation impacts based on agricultural research
  • Transparent sources: NASA API parameters clearly documented
  • Balanced messaging: Shows benefits AND drawbacks of each method

üåç Global Applicability

Multi-Region Support:

  • Works with any GPS coordinates globally
  • NASA POWER API covers entire planet
  • Players can compare farms in different climates (e.g., Brazil vs. India)

Localization Ready:

  • Metric system (hectares, Celsius, mm, m/s)
  • Internationalization (i18n) structure prepared for multiple languages

üìä Impact Metrics

Measurable Outcomes:

  • Sustainability Score: Quantifies environmental impact (0-100)
  • Resource Efficiency: Tracks water usage, fertilizer application
  • Yield Optimization: Compares actual vs. potential harvest
  • Cost-Benefit Analysis: Shows $/hectare vs. sustainability trade-offs

Long-term Vision:

  • Export farm reports for educational portfolios
  • Leaderboard to encourage competition
  • Achievement system to reward sustainable practices
  • Multiplayer mode for collaborative learning
projectDetails.aiReferences:
During Farm Flux development, I used AI tools (GitHub Copilot, Claude) as¬†coding assistants, not primary solution providers. AI helped with:

  • Debugging syntax errors and type mismatches
  • Suggesting code patterns and best practices
  • Generating boilerplate code and documentation
  • Identifying performance issues

All critical decisions remained human:

  • System architecture and design patterns
  • Game mechanics and sustainability algorithms
  • Educational content and feedback messages
  • NASA API integration strategy
  • User experience and interface design

AI accelerated routine tasks, allowing me to focus on creative problem-solving and educational value.

projectDetails.name: Orbit Credits Exchange (OCE)
projectDetails.summary:
The Orbit Credits Exchange (OCE) transforms orbital debris removal from a costly obligation into a sustainable economic ecosystem. Inspired by carbon markets, OCE introduces ‚Äúorbital credits‚Äù, a tradable currency that rewards debris removal and charges for orbital usage in Low Earth Orbit (LEO).

Through a digital marketplace, satellite operators pay orbital fees based on their time and mass in orbit, while missions that remove or recycle debris earn credits that can be resold. This creates a financial incentive for Active Debris Removal (ADR) and end-of-life compliance, turning orbital sustainability into a profitable venture.

OCE directly addresses the Commercializing LEO challenge by making sustainability financially viable. It leverages AI and blockchain for verification and transparency, and integrates public engagement through educational tools and crowdfunding.

By aligning space sustainability with market forces, OCE ensures that LEO remains safe, accessible, and economically vibrant for future generations.

challengeDetails.title: SpaceTrash Hack: Revolutionizing Recycling on Mars
challengeDetails.excerpt: During a hypothetical three-year mission to Mars and back, an eight-person crew would accumulate 12,600 kg of inorganic waste, or trash, including various packaging materials, textiles, and structural materials. This scenario creates a pressing need to recycle available materials, rather than execute the expensive and inefficient processes of transporting additional resources from Earth and/or sending trash back to Earth. As humans prepare to explore unknown worlds in the future, your challenge is to design sustainable systems that could manage, reuse, or recycle inorganic waste (‚Äútrash‚Äù) that is brought to and/or accumulated on the surface of Mars. (Space Technology Mission Directorate)

challengeDetails.title: Your Home in Space: The Habitat Layout Creator
challengeDetails.excerpt: Space habitats are ‚Äúhomes in space‚Äù that keep crew members healthy and able to execute their mission. Whether located on a planetary surface or in space, habitats must support critical functions such as waste management, thermal control, life support, communications, power, stowage, food storage and preparation, medical care, sleep, and exercise. Space habitat concepts can involve a diverse array of materials, geometries, and layouts. Your challenge is to create a visual tool that enables users to define a space habitat‚Äôs shape/volume and explore possible layout options. (Exploration Systems Development Mission Directorate)

projectDetails.name: Project KOIKWA
projectDetails.summary:
Koikwa 1 ‚Äì Buraco no C√©u is an educational Internet of Things (IoT) project designed to simulate satellite data acquisition and analysis. The system measures local environmental conditions‚Äîspecifically temperature‚Äîusing a BMP180 sensor connected to a Heltec V3 microcontroller, and compares these ground-based readings with satellite-derived temperature estimates from NASA‚Äôs POWER (Prediction of Worldwide Energy Resources) dataset.

Additionally, the project integrates a u-blox M10 GPS module to record geographic coordinates (latitude and longitude), ensuring accurate spatial correlation between local and satellite data. Data is transmitted via Bluetooth Low Energy (BLE) in real time to a connected application, where it is stored, visualized through dynamic graphs, and analyzed statistically to highlight variations and trends.

The overarching mission of Koikwa 1 ‚Äì Buraco no C√©u is to inspire scientific curiosity and technological learning among children by providing a hands-on demonstration of how IoT technologies and open-access satellite data can be combined to explore environmental science in an accessible and engaging way.

projectDetails.name: Project Koikwa 2
projectDetails.summary:
Our project, Koikwa 2 - Cotton Rope, is a space lander prototype designed as an educational tool for instrumentation, embedded electronics, sensing, and programming. We developed a system using a BBC micro:bit board and an HC-SR04 ultrasonic sensor to map surfaces by acquiring real-time distance and magnetic field data. The micro:bit's internal magnetometer measures the magnetic field, providing orientation and composition data, while the ultrasonic sensor determines the lander's altitude and maps the surface topography.
This prototype directly addresses the challenge by providing a hands-on, low-cost platform for learning essential space exploration technologies. Our project is deeply inspired by the origin story of the Kayap√≥ people of Brazil, whose ancestors descended from the sky on a long cotton rope. In their story, the stars represent their celestial ancestors. Our lander's descent to map a new world mirrors this mythological journey. This connection is important as it bridges modern space science with the rich, ancient cosmology of indigenous cultures, reminding us that the quest to understand our origins and explore new frontiers is a timeless, universal human endeavor.
projectDetails.details:
Inspiration: A Bridge Between Worlds

Our project is deeply rooted in the powerful origin story of the Meb√™ng√¥kre (Kayap√≥) people, an indigenous ethnicity from our home region in Uberl√¢ndia, Brazil. Their cosmology tells of ancestors who lived in the sky until a warrior discovered a passage to Earth. Enchanted by the world below, they decided to descend using a long rope made of cotton. For them, the stars are their celestial ancestors, a nightly reminder of their origins.

Our lander's mission‚Äîto descend from above and map an unknown world‚Äîis a direct technological parallel to this ancient journey. Our¬†"Cotton Rope"¬†is the stream of data connecting our probe to our control station. The goal of Koikwa 2 is to create a project that is not only scientifically functional but also rich in meaning, connecting the drive for space exploration with humanity's oldest stories about the cosmos.

How It Works: The Technical Mission

Koikwa 2 is a functional prototype built to demonstrate the core principles of a planetary lander's survey mission.

  • Hardware Core:¬†The brain of our lander is a¬†BBC micro:bit, a versatile and accessible microcontroller. It's connected to an¬†HC-SR04 ultrasonic sensor, which acts as a simple altimeter and surface scanner. The entire system is powered by a 3.7V LiPo battery, making it a self-contained unit.
    1. Topographical Mapping:¬†The HC-SR04 sensor emits ultrasonic pulses and measures the time it takes for the echo to return. Our code converts this time into a precise distance measurement, allowing the lander to map the height and contours of the surface below it.
    2. Magnetic Field Analysis:¬†Simultaneously, the micro:bit‚Äôs onboard magnetometer gathers magnetic field data (X, Y, Z axes). This data can be used to determine the lander's orientation and could potentially detect magnetic anomalies on a planetary surface.
  • Software & Data Stream:¬†The firmware was developed in¬†MicroPython, valued for its simplicity and power. The lander outputs a continuous stream of comma-separated values (CSV) in the format¬†distance_cm, magnetic_field_x, magnetic_field_y, magnetic_field_z¬†via a serial connection. This raw data can be easily logged, parsed, and visualized using simple scripts or even spreadsheet software.


How Our Project Addresses the Challenge

Koikwa 2 directly addresses the challenge of creating educational tools for space science in several ways:

  • Accessibility & Low Cost:¬†It uses off-the-shelf, affordable components, making space science accessible to students, hobbyists, and educators without large budgets.
  • Hands-On Learning:¬†It provides a tangible platform for learning fundamental skills in electronics, programming (MicroPython), sensor integration, and data analysis‚Äîthe very skills needed for a career in aerospace.
  • Inspiration & STEAM:¬†By connecting STEM with the Arts and Humanities (the "A" in STEAM), our project provides a powerful narrative hook to engage a wider and more diverse audience in the wonders of space exploration.

projectDetails.name: The Secrets of Space Weather
projectDetails.summary:
Our project, ‚ÄúThe Secrets of Space Weather‚Äù, focuses on teaching kids about space weather through a fun and educational game. The main goal is to make complex scientific concepts, such as solar flares, CMEs, radiation storms, and their effects on Earth, accessible and engaging for young learners. We developed an interactive digital game that combines storytelling, colorful visuals, and simple challenges to encourage curiosity and understanding of how the Sun influences our planet.

To address the challenge of limited awareness and education about space weather among children, "The Secrets of Space Weather" uses gamified learning techniques and playful interaction. The game provides short missions where players learn about solar activity and understand the importance of space weather in our lives. This approach transforms abstract scientific data into relatable, hands-on experiences.

"The Secrets of Space Weather" is important because it bridges the gap between science and education, inspiring the next generation to explore astronomy and space science. By presenting real scientific ideas in a creative and age-appropriate way, the project promotes STEM education (Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics) and helps build a foundation for future scientific curiosity and understanding.
projectDetails.details:
The mysteries of space weather and its influence on Earth are often seen as complex and distant subjects, but they can directly affect our daily lives. Solar flares, coronal mass ejections, and geomagnetic storms can interfere with communication systems, navigation, and even power grids. Despite their importance, these phenomena are rarely explored in an accessible way for young audiences.

To change this, we created ‚ÄúThe Secrets of Space Weather‚Äù, a digital educational game¬† that combines science, art, and storytelling to introduce children and teenagers aged 10 to 15 years to the fascinating world of space weather ‚Äî in a fun and interactive way.

The story follows Luma, a curious girl passionate about science who embarks on a journey guided by her scientist friend, Dr.Brall, to discover what space weather is and how it affects people around the world. Across three exciting phases, Luma meets different characters such as a pilot struggling with signal loss, a photographer chasing auroras, and astronauts facing dangerous solar radiation. Throughout these, Luma meets not only people impacted by the space weather but also the personified phenomena themselves. Each event, like a Solar Flare, an Aurora Borealis or a Radiation Storm, becomes a living character who explains its origins and behavior. These unique interactions allow children to learn from both sides of the story: the people who experience the effects and the solar phenomena that cause them. Each encounter includes playful dialogues that translate scientific concepts into easy understanding comparisons and mini-games that reinforce learning in a fun way.
projectDetails.aiReferences: Our use of AI was strictly limited to text correction and suggestion within the script. As native Portuguese speakers, we naturally face a language barrier; accordingly, a significant portion of the English text was generated with the assistance of AI. In other words, the script was originally authored entirely in Portuguese and subsequently translated into English. More broadly, AI was employed solely to correct certain code snippets, and its use did not extend beyond that.

projectDetails.name: A.I.M. - Aegis Impact Model
projectDetails.summary: A.I.M. (Aegis Impact Model) is a visualization and predictive system designed to simulate and analyze scenarios in which celestial bodies collide with Earth. The platform leverages Large Language Models (LLMs) to generate analytical reports based on the selected impact location, detailing instantaneous, economic, and environmental consequences, as well as physical parameters such as released energy and impact radius. Users can fully customize meteor parameters, including composition, diameter (0‚Äì100 km), velocity, and impact angle, enabling the exploration of a wide range of collision scenarios across different regions of the planet. The project aims to serve as both a scientific and exploratory tool, providing a dynamic environment for impact assessment and educational visualization. Future expanded versions of A.I.M. are envisioned to incorporate pre-impact prediction and post-impact analysis, creating a comprehensive framework for understanding and modeling the complete lifecycle of meteor events.
projectDetails.details:
INTRODUCTION

According to the Statistical Discovery Report from the Center for Near-Earth Object Studies (CNEOS), nearly 40,000 Near-Earth Objects (NEOs) have been discovered to date. With a significant number of these bodies passing close to Earth, and with recorded impact events such as the Chelyabinsk Event (2013), the study and prediction of potential impact scenarios are of critical importance. Accurate forecasting of such events has the potential to mitigate risks and ultimately save lives.

[Image 1 - CNEOS Close Approach Visualization 2025 SY10]

THE NECESSITY

Given the vast number of objects passing near Earth, the probability of collisions with our planet remains a significant parameter to consider. Through the use of advanced computational and analytical technologies, predicting all possible impact scenarios based on an asteroid‚Äôs physical composition and trajectory becomes an invaluable approach to mitigating potential threats.

From an educational perspective, such a tool could serve as an exceptional resource for academic research, classroom studies, and scientific outreach, enhancing understanding of celestial dynamics and planetary defense.

THE SOLUTION

Powered by artificial intelligence, A.I.M. can generate a comprehensive range of statistical and analytical data that may assist governmental and environmental agencies in mitigating the environmental, economic, and social impacts of potential meteor events within a given region.

[Image 2 - A.I.M.'s Main Screen]

Beyond its scientific applications, the system also serves as a valuable educational platform for universities, schools, and research institutions, expanding knowledge about asteroids while enabling users to simulate and analyze real-world problem-solving scenarios.

[Image 3 - A.I.M.'s Config Screen]

The DEMO version of A.I.M. allows for full customization of meteor parameters, supporting diameters of up to 100 kilometers, thereby encompassing not only minor but also catastrophic impact scenarios. It features an interactive 3D visualization of the Earth, providing a highly immersive simulation experience.

For the development of this DEMO, Gemini 2.5 Flash was employed to process and interpret data based on the user-selected impact location, ensuring accuracy and dynamic adaptation of simulated conditions.

[Image 4 - A.I.M.'s DEMO A.I. Report]

TECHNOLOGIES UTILIZED

The A.I.M. system integrates AI-powered and map visualization APIs, while maintaining a lightweight core architecture built primarily with HTML, CSS, and JavaScript. These core technologies handle the rendering, styling, and mathematical computations required to visualize impact radius and released energy based on the meteor‚Äôs defined parameters.

The web application is deployed on Vercel and fully integrated with GitHub for continuous development and version control. Its core logic is implemented in HTML, CSS, and JavaScript, while external APIs including Gemini 2.5 Flash for AI-driven data interpretation and Mapbox for geospatial visualization extend its analytical and interactive capabilities.

[Image 5 - Application Architeture Diagram]

challengeDetails.title: Sharks from Space
challengeDetails.excerpt: Earth‚Äôs ocean is one of the most powerful habitats in our universe, supporting a range of life that sustains ecosystems and habitability across the globe. It is common to measure photosynthetic activity in the ocean from space, but far more challenging to track top predators. Your challenge is to create a mathematical framework for identifying sharks and predicting their foraging habitats using NASA satellite data, and also to suggest a new conceptual model of a tag (a small electronic device that can be attached to an animal to track and study its movement) that could measure not only where sharks are, but also what they are eating, and in real time transmit that data back to users to enable development of predictive models. (Earth Science Division)

projectDetails.name: Project EcoPulse
projectDetails.summary:
Our project aims to improve access to healthcare and promote sustainability in Uberl√¢ndia, focusing on vulnerable areas with limited infrastructure that are sensitive to extreme climate variations. The lack of accessible healthcare facilities and the worsening of health conditions due to climate change are critical challenges. To mitigate these problems, we propose an integrated system that involves the distribution of smart watches to monitor the health of vulnerable populations. These devices, which measure blood pressure, heart rate, blood oxygenation, and detect falls, help prevent serious complications and enable rapid intervention. In case of anomalies, the watch sends an alert via radio waves to the healthcare system, triggering mobile health stations.
These mobile stations will be deployed seasonally to the regions most in need, based on detailed data on climate and extreme environmental conditions, such as air quality, extreme temperatures, and other climatic factors. This ensures that medical care is optimized for areas at greatest risk of health problems due to climatic conditions. In addition, the clocks will be made from recyclable materials, promoting the city's sustainability. The system aims not only to improve the efficiency of medical care, but also to offer a response tailored to the needs of each community, preventing health complications and ensuring rapid action when most needed.
projectDetails.details:
EcoPulse ‚Äì Project Document

1.0 Questions to Be Answered

1.1 What It Does

The project aims to improve access to healthcare and promote sustainability in Uberl√¢ndia, focusing on vulnerable areas with limited infrastructure and sensitivity to extreme climate variations.

1.2 How It Works

The system is integrated and involves the distribution of smartwatches to monitor the health of vulnerable populations. These devices measure blood pressure, heart rate, blood oxygen levels, and detect falls. In case of anomalies, the watches send alerts via radio waves to the healthcare system, activating mobile units.

1.3 Benefits

  • Prevention of serious complications through continuous monitoring.

  • Rapid and efficient response with deployment of mobile units.

  • Improved healthcare management and reduced hospital overload.

1.4 Intention

  • Promote sustainability by using recyclable materials in the manufacture of the watches.

  • Ensure efficiency and inclusion in medical care, prioritizing vulnerable populations.

1.5 Impacts

  • Facilitated access to healthcare in regions with limited infrastructure.

  • Encouragement of sustainability through eco-friendly materials.

  • Reduction of severe medical emergencies and social inequality.

1.6 Considered Factors

  • Social vulnerability and extreme climatic conditions (air quality, temperature, rainfall).

  • Seasonal allocation of mobile units based on climate and environmental data.

2.0 Research

2.1 What It Does

The project aims to contribute to the development of Uberl√¢ndia, making it more sustainable and healthy. The smartwatch promotes social inclusion in healthcare, prioritizing vulnerable populations and increasing access to health posts.

2.2 How It Works

Watch Description Inspired by modern smartwatches and sphygmomanometers, the watch measures:

  • Blood pressure (Korotkoff sounds)

  • Heart rate (BPM)

  • Blood oxygen saturation (SpO‚ÇÇ)

  • Fall detection

Data is displayed on the screen and via audio, and transmitted via radio to medical systems. The material is recyclable and features an emergency button, audio output, and an inclusive interface for visually impaired users. The battery is rechargeable, and the design prioritizes accessibility and durability.

Alerts and Interventions In emergency situations:

  • The healthcare system receives automatic alerts.

  • Mobile units are dispatched to the location.

  • Care can be provided on-site or referred to a nearby hospital.

Mobile units also operate in regions with extreme climatic conditions, according to NASA data.

2.3 Mobile Units

Adapted vans function as mobile medical units, equipped with examination kits and direct communication with healthcare services. They are operated by interns and medical students in partnership with universities.

2.4 Benefits, Intention, and Impacts

  • Continuous health monitoring.

  • Rapid and precise medical response.

  • Technological and social inclusion.

  • Sustainability and optimization of public resources.

2.5 Considered Factors

  • Social Vulnerability: Identification of areas with limited infrastructure and high climatic risk.

  • Seasonality: Mobile units are allocated according to climate and environmental data to maximize efficiency.

2.6 Tools Used

NASA Resources

  • EU Copernicus Global Human Settlement Layer (GHSL)

  • NASA Socioeconomic Data and Applications Center (SEDAC)

  • WorldPop

Partners

  • INPE (National Institute for Space Research)

  • INDE (National Spatial Data Infrastructure ‚Äì Brazil)

3.0 Chat Research (Complementary Summary)

3.1 What It Does

Promotes a sustainable and healthy city with a smartwatch focused on social inclusion in healthcare.

3.2 How It Works

The watch monitors blood pressure, BPM, SpO‚ÇÇ, and falls, sending data via radio and generating automatic alerts. Manufactured with recyclable materials and an accessible interface.

3.3 Benefits and Impacts

  • Emergency prevention.

  • Rapid and inclusive healthcare.

  • Reduction of inequalities.

  • Environmental sustainability.

3.4 Considered Factors

  • Social and climate vulnerability.

  • Seasonality and environmental data to prioritize interventions.

4.0 Mobile Units ‚Äì Improvement

Mobile health units, implemented through adapted vans, already exist in Uberl√¢ndia, but the proposal is to enhance this infrastructure, making it more efficient in serving vulnerable communities.

4.1 Functioning and Integration

When the watch detects an anomaly, it automatically sends an alert to the healthcare system. The nearest van is dispatched, receiving the data and navigating to the location with real-time information.

4.2 Seasonality and Planning

The distribution of vans will be optimized according to climate risks, such as heat waves and increased pollution, ensuring strategic deployment.

4.3 Equipment and Training

Vans will be equipped with full medical kits, direct communication with hospitals, and trained personnel, ensuring integrated healthcare delivery.

4.4 Benefits for the Community

This enhancement transforms mobile units into continuous connection points between citizens and the healthcare system, preventing severe emergencies and improving service efficiency.

5.0 Links Used and Applications

5.1 Copernicus ‚Äì UCDB 2024 Visual

European Union (EU) Copernicus Global Human Settlement Layer (GHSL)

  • Socioeconomic: Life expectancy increased from 2000-2015 but decreased from 2015-2020, highlighting the challenge of maintaining a healthy and sustainable city.
  • Danger and Risk: Increased risks from 2014-2016, mainly linked to heat waves affecting cardiovascular and respiratory health, potentially causing fainting.
  • Climate: Average annual temperature increased 2.5¬∞C (1970-2010) with projections until 2030, showing the direct impact of climate change on health.
  • Emissions: Increase in pollutant and CO‚ÇÇ emissions (1975-2020), intensifying the greenhouse effect and respiratory diseases.
  • Healthcare: Average of 6 hospitals per 100,000 inhabitants in Uberl√¢ndia (approx. 42 for 760,000 inhabitants), low considering demand.



  • Access: Between 300,000‚Äì400,000 people live more than 1 km from a hospital, evidencing difficulty of access in vulnerable areas.

5.2 GHSL ‚Äì Global Human Settlement Layer

European Union (EU) Copernicus Global Human Settlement Layer (GHSL)

¬†Used to identify vulnerable suburban zones (in yellow), essential for planning mobile unit distribution.

5.3 INPE ‚Äì Map Catalog

Brazilian Space Research Institute (INPE) Catalogue

Geographic database for evaluating regions of Uberl√¢ndia, supporting mapping of social and environmental vulnerabilities.

challengeDetails.title: Data Pathways to Healthy Cities and Human Settlements
challengeDetails.excerpt: Climate change brings about new complexities to consider for maintaining the wellbeing of society and the environment in cities. Natural resources, ecosystems, and existing infrastructure all must be monitored to ensure human quality of life remains high. Your challenge is to demonstrate how an urban planner can use NASA Earth observation data to develop smart strategies for city growth that maintain both the wellbeing of people and the environment. (Earth Science Division)

challengeDetails.title: Build a Space Biology Knowledge Engine
challengeDetails.excerpt: Enable a new era of human space exploration! NASA has been performing biology experiments in space for decades, generating a tremendous amount of information that will need to be considered as humans prepare to revisit the Moon and explore Mars. Although this knowledge is publicly available, it can be difficult for potential users to find information that pertains to their specific interests. Your challenge is to build a dynamic dashboard that leverages artificial intelligence (AI), knowledge graphs, and/or other tools to summarize a set of NASA bioscience publications and enables users to explore the impacts and results of the experiments these publications describe. (Earth Science Division)

challengeDetails.title: Will It Rain On My Parade?
challengeDetails.excerpt: If you‚Äôre planning an outdoor event‚Äîlike a vacation, a hike on a trail, or fishing on a lake‚Äîit would be good to know the chances of adverse weather for the time and location you are considering. There are many types of Earth observation data that can provide information on weather conditions for a particular location and day of the year. Your challenge is to construct an app with a personalized interface that enables users to conduct a customized query to tell them the likelihood of ‚Äúvery hot,‚Äù ‚Äúvery cold,‚Äù ‚Äúvery windy,‚Äù ‚Äúvery wet,‚Äù or ‚Äúvery uncomfortable‚Äù conditions for the location and time they specify. (Earth Science Division)

challengeDetails.title: A World Away: Hunting for Exoplanets with AI
challengeDetails.excerpt: Data from several different space-based exoplanet surveying missions have enabled discovery of thousands of new planets outside our solar system, but most of these exoplanets were identified manually. With advances in artificial intelligence and machine learning (AI/ML), it is possible to automatically analyze large sets of data collected by these missions to identify exoplanets. Your challenge is to create an AI/ML model that is trained on one or more of the open-source exoplanet datasets offered by NASA and that can analyze new data to accurately identify exoplanets. (Astrophysics Division)

projectDetails.name: The Day the Sun Messed with Everything.
projectDetails.summary:
Our project, ‚ÄúThe Day the Sun Messed with Everything,‚Äù is an educational illustrated story designed to explain the effects of solar activity on everyday life in a simple and engaging way. We developed a narrative that follows different characters ‚Äî a farmer, a pilot, an astronaut, an engineer, and a child ‚Äî all experiencing the impacts of a solar storm from their unique perspectives.

The project addresses the challenge of making complex scientific phenomena, like solar flares and geomagnetic storms, accessible to children and the general public. By connecting these events to relatable daily situations, readers can better understand how solar energy influences technology, communication, and life on Earth.

This is important because increasing awareness of space weather helps people appreciate the Sun‚Äôs power and the importance of science in predicting and protecting our planet from its effects.
projectDetails.details:
Our project, ‚ÄúThe Day the Sun Messed with Everything,‚Äù is an interactive educational story that demonstrates how solar activity can affect life on Earth. It works by combining storytelling, visual illustrations, and science communication to explain complex phenomena ‚Äî such as solar flares, magnetic storms, and their effects on satellites, communication systems, and power grids ‚Äî in a way that is accessible to all ages, especially children.

The main benefit of this project is its ability to transform scientific knowledge into an engaging learning experience. Readers gain awareness of the importance of solar observation and space weather research, while also developing curiosity about science, technology, and environmental awareness.

The intended impact is to promote scientific literacy and help communities understand how solar energy influences everyday technologies ‚Äî from airplanes and electricity to GPS and internet systems.

We developed the project using Canva for graphic design. The creativity lies in the fusion of storytelling and real-world science ‚Äî turning a potential global issue into an inspiring, easy-to-understand narrative.

Our team considered clarity, age-appropriate language, cultural inclusivity, and scientific accuracy to ensure the story educates, entertains, and empowers readers to appreciate the Sun‚Äôs vital role in our lives.

challengeDetails.title: Stellar Stories: Space Weather Through the Eyes of Earthlings
challengeDetails.excerpt: Although the Sun is 93 million miles away from our planet, solar activity can significantly impact our daily lives. ‚ÄúSpace weather‚Äù‚Äîthe variations that occur in the space environment between the Sun and Earth‚Äîcan impact technologies in space and on Earth. Your challenge is to write and illustrate a digital children‚Äôs story that explains what space weather is and the varying impacts it has on different people such as farmers, pilots, astronauts, power grid operators, and the general public. You can tell the story from the perspective of a person impacted by space weather or from the point of view of a solar flare or coronal mass ejection (CME) as it approaches Earth. (Heliophysics Division)

challengeDetails.excerpt: NASA‚Äôs Tropospheric Emissions: Monitoring of Pollution (TEMPO) mission is revolutionizing air quality monitoring across North America by enabling better forecasts and reducing pollutant exposure. Your challenge is to develop a web-based app that forecasts air quality by integrating real-time TEMPO data with ground-based air quality measurements and weather data, notifying users of poor air quality, and helping to improve public health decisions. Teams are encouraged to utilize new technologies that allow seamless scaling of computing from local devices to cloud systems, enhancing collaboration and streamlining work efficiency. (Earth Science Division)

challengeDetails.title: Commercializing Low Earth Orbit (LEO)
challengeDetails.excerpt: As the commercialization of space rapidly accelerates, the future of business in low Earth orbit (LEO) holds incredible potential, but also presents significant operational, regulatory, and environmental challenges. This new economic frontier invites innovative and sustainable approaches to foster long-term viability and responsible execution. Your challenge is to conceptualize and design a scalable, sustainable, business model, accompanied by a prototype, that explores the unique opportunities LEO offers while addressing the complexities of operating in space. (Joint Agency Satellite Division)

challengeDetails.title: Deep Dive: Immersive Data Stories from Ocean to Sky
challengeDetails.excerpt: Satellite observations reveal insights about our dynamic home planet to scientists, but people without a remote sensing background often find the stories within these datasets difficult to access. NASA‚Äôs open data policy makes these observations available to everyone‚Äîscientists and non-scientists alike. Your challenge is to build a short, immersive, virtual reality (VR) experience that leverages NASA‚Äôs Earth observation datasets and visualizations to bring stories about our planet‚Äôs oceans to life, connecting a broad audience to this data, its beauty, and its impact. Using visuals, spatial audio, and even interactive elements, your VR experience can enable users to dive deeper into Earth‚Äôs unfolding ocean story. (Earth Science Division)

challengeDetails.title: SpaceTrash Hack: Revolutionizing Recycling on Mars
challengeDetails.excerpt: During a hypothetical three-year mission to Mars and back, an eight-person crew would accumulate 12,600 kg of inorganic waste, or trash, including various packaging materials, textiles, and structural materials. This scenario creates a pressing need to recycle available materials, rather than execute the expensive and inefficient processes of transporting additional resources from Earth and/or sending trash back to Earth. As humans prepare to explore unknown worlds in the future, your challenge is to design sustainable systems that could manage, reuse, or recycle inorganic waste (‚Äútrash‚Äù) that is brought to and/or accumulated on the surface of Mars. (Space Technology Mission Directorate)
